Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S1N-JTF1-DXH2-64HS-00000-00The left's irrational response to shootings; Protected tech billionaires want gun control; Outrage of Trump plan for Syria pullout; Why the left makes everything about race; "Tech Tyranny": Google's China investments could hurt America; Hillary's Excuse Tour: Now even stranger; Police: Raccoons acting strangely in Ohio2018-04-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:33:52ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTJoel Payne, David Tafuri, Christopher Harris, Paul Scharre, Tammy BruceNEWSDomestic040401cb.260The left's irrational response to shootings; Protected tech billionaires want gun control; Outrage of Trump plan for Syria pullout; Why the left makes everything about race; "Tech Tyranny": Google's China investments could hurt America; Hillary's Excuse Tour: Now even stranger; Police: Raccoons acting strangely in OhioTucker Carlson, Pete Hegseth

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Well, good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

A shooting yesterday at YouTube's headquarters in California wounded three people, but left only the shooter dead.

The killer was an Iranian refugee named Nasim Aghdam. Apparently, Aghdam believed that YouTube's content policies have somehow sabotaged her efforts to become a digital video star. Enraged, she drove to the company's headquarters and opened fire. That's what we know.

Now, let's pause for a moment and pretend this is not the 8 p.m. show on Fox News. Let's pretend it's somewhere else on the dial. Maybe "CNN" or "MSNBC" or actually any other cable channel or newspaper in America.

If that were true, by definition, we'd have to draw hard-and-fast conclusions from this tragedy using the limited facts that are available. We don't really know much at this stage, but sweeping dumb generalizations are what the media do. We would do that. And, of course, we'd need a very specific script in order to make those generalizations.

So, what do we conclude from what happened yesterday? Well, first off, the shooter was a woman. She was female. So, clearly, America has a problem with toxic feminity. And we need to address that crisis right away, starting with more university panel shaming an entire gender. Somebody alert the HR department to this.

And then, there is the gun. We focus relentlessly on the gun because nothing is more pivotal in a shooting than the weapon that was used. It's always the gun's fault. Always.

The shooter in this case used a Smith & Wesson 9 mm handgun. Those guns need to be banned tomorrow, along with all other assault pistols. Now, if you disagree with that, you're evil.

Next, the shooter was a vegan and a supporter of PETA. Therefore, PETA is now a terrorist organization. Anyone who supports PETA, even though supporters who disapprove of mass shootings, is a monster and has blood on his hands.

Let's hope that "CNN" hosts a town hall meeting where YouTube employees can scream at PETA spokesman. They deserved to be screaned at. They caused the shooting.

But, wait, media outlets aren't reaching any of those conclusions. Why not? Well, because there's no obvious way to use this shooting to advance the objectives of the Democratic Party. So, the media will stop talking about it soon. That's how corrupt they are.

They're also incredibly stupid, especially on the subject of firearms. The people yelling at you about guns on television aren't sure what end the bullet comes out. They're kids. They're children with all the ignorance and moral certainty of fifth graders.

We can show you a million examples of that because they are everywhere, but here's the most amusing one we've seen recently. It happened yesterday.

This is MSNBC's resident genius Nicolle Wallace mistaking the opening of a soda can for gunfire. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NICOLLE WALLACE, "MSNBC" HOST, "DEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE": Steve Smith, I always go back to the horror of 9/11 and the complete reliance - we're in our tribes. We're in our corners most of our lives. I think we just heard some gunshots. Should we listen to that for a second, control room? That's not a gun shot.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Not gunshots? No, Nicolle, not gunshots. Pretty funny. But be certain to listen very carefully if she lectures about the Second Amendment because she knows a lot about it.

Pete Hegseth is "Fox & friends" weekend host. He is a former member of the US military, a decorated one, and he joins us tonight.

So, Pete, it's a pretty simple question. We kind of know the script. We know the way these things unfold, how they're analyzed in the press. We draw sweeping conclusions from a pretty limited set of facts. You're not hearing that tonight. You're not hearing other channels say toxic femininity as a threat to America. Why is that?

PETE HEGSETH, "FOX & FRIENDS" WEEKEND HOST: Well, of course, you're not wrong bad guy, Tucker. Wrong bad guy.

Female of Iranian descent. She's a fitness buff. She's a vegan. She's a PETA member. Not an NRA member. Not a Trump supporter. Not a member of the NRA. And as a result, doesn't fit the very convenient narrative. And as a result, it's silenced, Tucker.

I mean, it is "NBC", "CBS" negligent coverage. "ABC" glancing blow. "NBC" said she's apparently an animal rights activist. They are moving away from this as quickly as they can with almost - imagine if it was an NRA member that did this. Is he apparently an NRA member or is he actually an NRA member?

In this case, apparently an animal rights activists, but no judgment or blood on the hands of a PETA member. Always blood on the hands of an NRA member because it would be absurd to me to define an entire population as violent because they believe in animal rights, just like it's absurd to believe an entire population of Second Amendment supporters that believes in violence because they support our rights.

CARLSON: So, I'm a little confused here. So, what you're suggesting - and my producer just said in my ear. He's watching the other channels. None of them are covering this right now - that the coverage of gun crimes really isn't an effort to reduce the number of gun crimes. It's an effort to make a series of partisan points. Is that what you're saying?

HEGSETH: It's an effort to impugn the Second Amendment and those who support it, Tucker. Ultimately, it all depends on the labels that apply. You know this. Identity politics are one-sided.

If you're a white Christian male who voted for Donald Trump and believe in the Second Amendment who owns an AR-15, then you must be - have a proclivity to violence.

But you are a female of any other shade who owns a handgun and supports animals and you commit violence, nothing to see here, turn this channel. "Good morning America", as they did this morning, will not even cover this deal, this shooting and won't draw a larger narrative as a result.

Again, apparently an animal rights activist. This is what the modern media has turned into, cheerleading for a cause, which is taking away our guns, which is exactly what we know they want to do as opposed to reporting the news and then moving on if it's not relevant.

CARLSON: It doesn't sound like journalism. It does seem to me that it crosses a line when it moves from attacking the president personally - they don't like Trump. I get it. He doesn't like them, by the way.

HEGSETH: Sure.

CARLSON: But from that - which you could sort of understand it. You know you probably shouldn't do it, but I get it - to moving over to advocating for specific policies that affect 320 million Americans as if there's only one side of the debate.

It moves from childish annoyance to full-on propaganda.

HEGSETH: Of course. I've heard journalists on other networks say it is our obligation to continue to talk about the Parkland shooting because we owe it to the American people to keep the conversation alive.

If we don't talk about it, the conversation doesn't continue and policies don't change in Washington DC. If that doesn't sound like activism, I don't know what is.

I mean, it's your job to report the news that is relevant and the shooting - a mass shooting is, of course, relevant. You cover it and then you move on as necessary. They're deciding what to coverage and dwell on to try to change -

CARLSON: That's right. But what's so striking is, if you're going to pick a topic that the media would lobby on, maybe camera angles or lighting, they sort of makeup - I mean, they're experts on that stuff. But is there any group in America that knows less about firearms? Nicolle Wallace mistook a soda opening for a gunshot.

HEGSETH: I opened my Diet Mountain Dew, which I happen to like, and no one around here jumped and thought it was an AR-15, let alone a 9 mm. I mean, I need Diet Mountain Dew because I'm up at six in the morning like you used to be. It keeps us awake. But I've never mistaken nor would anyone I know would mistake that as gun fire.

They they know nothing, Tucker. How many members of this media are members of the NRA? How many of them have ever fired an AR-15, let alone an M4, which I carry, let alone a 249 squad automatic weapon.

They don't know a squad automatic weapon from a BB gun, yet they're going to tell me what I what I can or cannot carry. Of course, it's political activism to help their Democratic buddies.

There is a tank. It's not convenient. They're not going to cover it.

CARLSON: Who put all the dumb people on TV? I always ask myself that. Pete, it's great to see you. You're not one of them. And I appreciate your coming on.

HEGSETH: Thank you.

CARLSON: Thank you.

Well, several tech CEOs responded to the YouTube shooting by demanding that regular people be deprived off their right to carry firearms.

That would include Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey who tweeted this, "We can't keep being reactive to this and thinking and praying it won't happen again in our schools, jobs, our community spots. It is beyond time to evolve our policies." He didn't specify which ones, but you know what he was talking about. He cares much more than you do.

Dorsey then endorsed demands issued by the March for our Lives. Those would include, again not specific, banning high-capacity magazines, confiscating all weapons designated as assault weapons.

Now, what's interesting about all this is that, in 2015, Twitter, the company he runs, spent more than $68,000 providing, yes, personal security to Jack Dorsey.

Were those guards unarmed? Right. No, they weren't.

Joel Payne is former director of African-American advertising for Hillary Clinton's 2016 campaigns and he joins us tonight.

Great to see you, Joel. I appreciate your coming on. So, it's hard to read this as anything else but an effort by the people in charge to bring more power to themselves, which is what people in charge do kind of instinctively. We get the guns. you don't. Shut up and obey. Why is that not what's happening right now.

JOEL PAYNE, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Tucker, I don't think really think that's the right way to look at this issue. And I really enjoyed listening to your conversation with your colleague a little bit earlier.

I am interested to here that you guy think that it's funny that someone on TV in this environment thought that a soda can opening was a gunshot. You thought that was funny.

CARLSON: I think it's idiotic. Just to clarify, I want to say that I think it's idiotic. But that studio didn't have gunshots. It had a soda opening.

And my point is that, if you're going to advocate for positions, you have a moral obligation to learn something about the topic. And most people who are doing that haven't bothered to learn. And that's the problem.

I'm not in any way denigrating the fear people feel in the face of gunfire. I'm making fun of people mistaking a Mountain Dew can for gunfire.

Look, the point is ordinary people are afraid. You're absolutely right. We agree on that. So, why would the people in charge who are protected by armed security demand that no one else be allowed to protect themselves, if you see what I mean?

PAYNE: Well, I have some frustration towards what I heard from the Twitter CEO today, but for a different reason. I don't like this trend that we have of waiting for gun violence to come to your backyard before you get worke about it. I mean, just because it happened at a tech company yesterday, as you got this letter with all these tech CEOs who decided to sign on.

Listen, I was touched recently by gun violence. I had a very close friend that was impacted by what happened at the veteran home in California. But, guess what, I felt strongly about gun violence and about all of the concerns around that before that. It didn't take that issue to pique my interest.

By the way, it's interesting, Tucker. A lot of the people who watch this show and a lot of people who watch this network feel the same way I do.

If you look at the polls -

CARLSON: Well, I feel the same way you do.

(CROSSTALK)

CARLSON: No, no, but hold on. Let's be honest. One of the sort of pieces of political rhetoric that drives me the craziest is the idea that only a select few care about gun violence.

I think most people, most normal people are horrified by shootings. I know I am. So, the question is not do you feel deeply about or are you upset. Of course, you're upset. The question is what's the most effective response? What's the wise thing to do? That's where the debate is. It's not over who cares and who doesn't. Everybody cares. I mean, come on now.

PAYNE: So, yes, I would turn that question back to you and say, what should we do?

CARLSON: Well, I'll give you a perfect example. So, with the Parkland shooting, we have a well-documented string of failures by people whose job it was to protect the kids in that school. And they didn't.

There were four armed cops outside - four! - who heard the gunfire and didn't go in. I never heard their names mentioned at the March for our Lives. I doubt you know their names. I never heard anybody mention that.

We hire people to protect those kids. Seventeen were murdered because they didn't act, but it's the NRA's fault? That's insane. That's just pure politics. You're not taking it seriously if you reach that conclusion, I would say.

PAYNE: Yes. Sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt you. There were a lot of people who failed those children that day. Some of them were the people who didn't run into those building, but a number were people who were in the State House in Tallahassee and who were on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C.

They had the chance to act. You could have acted after Sandy Hook. You could have acted after Orlando (ph). You had so many opportunities to act.

CARLSON: You're defending the people in power, as almost everyone in the left does, the people in power are blameless. They didn't do anything wrong.

It's you out there who've committed no crime whatsoever. The guns in my closet, if I had them, would be no threat to anybody, but I have to disarm, but the cops whose job it was to protect the kids, they're cool. We can't blame them.

PAYNE: I didn't say that. I actually agreed with you. I said they share some blame. I said that the blame didn't end with them, though. It also extended to the people who were in Tallahassee at their State Houses and in Capitol Hill and State Houses all across the country who failed to act.

CARLSON: I mean, I take you seriously. It's why I wanted to talk to you tonight. So, just in the minute and a half we have left, just give me a discreet step, specific step that they could have taken to prevent the Parkland shooting, for example.

PAYNE: Well, let's look at a couple of things. Why hasn't the president acted on bump stocks. I thought he was hot to trot on that.

CARLSON: What does that have to do with Parkland? Bump stock makes your rifle less accurate. See, this is like - you don't know anything about guns.

PAYNE: Here's the problem, though, Tucker. Your answer here is, well, it wouldn't stop this specific act.

CARLSON: I am asking an honest question, which is what's -

PAYNE: We have a gun violence culture.

CARLSON: So, you're blaming the State House in Tallahassee for our culture?

PAYNE: Actually, I am. We have a laissez faire culture to gun violence.

CARLSON: OK. When I asked you an adult question -

PAYNE: We have a culture that has accepted that gun violence is something we can't do anything about when we know we can.

CARLSON: I feel it is something we can do something about. And when armed guards neglect their duty to protect children, I think we should hold them accountable.

You instead shifted the blame from the people who actually had power to people whose other positions you don't like in the State House, Republicans.

I asked then - trying to be rational - what should they have done? And you said Trump should ban bump stocks, which had no role in the Parkland shooting.

PAYNE: I didn't finish. I was going to say a little bit more. The president can act on this. by the way, the NRA, they could be partners here, right?

The NRA are running scared. The reason why you see them turning John Paul Stevens and a bunch of 17 year olds into boogeymen is because they know public sentiment is at an all-time low for what they fight for, which is the right for gun manufacturers to make money.

CARLSON: But you're arguing rhetoric and bumper stickers. I want actual solutions because, like you, I care. I want to know what the new law is that would have prevented Parkland.

There are a lot of shootings. Lot of different causes. I asked for one specific answer to that one and I got bump stocks and John Paul Stevens.

PAYNE: I can give you more.

CARLSON: How about one.

PAYNE: We can restrict access to people who are mentally ill.

CARLSON: We already have done that.

PAYNE: We can stop terrorists from purchasing guns. We could have done that. Congress wouldn't do that. You've got Toomey's legislation. You've got Manchin's legislation.

CARLSON: We already have the laws.

PAYNE: You've got Durbin's legislation. So many people have tried to act on this, but the intransigence in Washington led by the NRA won't allow it.

CARLSON: That's a lie. If you go buy a gun, it screams people who are mentally ill. The authorities, the actual authorities failed to screen this kid despite the fact everyone knew he was mentally ill. They didn't anything.

PAYNE: Unfortunately, the majority of Americans and the majority of Republicans actually disagree with you and the polling reflects that.

CARLSON: OK. I don't know what to say. Those are the facts. Joe, thank you. Thank you for coming on.

PAYNE: Thank you.

CARLSON: I appreciate it.

Well, at the top of the show, one of our guests mentioned that "GMA" did not cover the YouTube shooting. In fact, that show did spend time on the shooting this morning over the course of a couple of hours. We wanted to correct that.

Washington elites are horrified that the president may want to send troops to guard our border, but they're also horrified that those troops may have to leave Syria. It tells you everything about their priorities and we're going to unpack for you next.

CARLSON: Every once in a while, one of those stories comes along where the red light goes off and you suddenly understand what's going on just beneath the surface. It all makes sense.

That happened today. So, the administration recently suggested it wants to pull American troops out of Syria now that ISIS has been crushed and the official mission has been achieved.

How did Washington react to this, the idea that our troops might come home? Totally outraged.

Sen. Lindsey Graham, the Republican of South Carolina, called that "the single worst decision the president could make."

Others imputed darker motives. A writer called Amy Siskind tweeted this, "After our military discussed sending in more troops, Trump suddenly and unilaterally decides to pull our troops out. Who does this help (hint: Putin)!"

Unilaterally? Hilarious. He's the president.

Well, "CNN" and "The Washington Post", of course, made the same claim. If you don't support yet another foreign war with no clear objective or end date, you're in league with our enemies. You're unpatriotic.

They tell us American troops absolutely have to be fighting in Syria. OK. You've heard that for years. But at the same time, they tell us that American troops absolutely should not be protecting America's own borders.

The Trump administration has signed an executive order deploying the National Guard to the Mexican border, part of an effort to halt illegal immigration.

The people in charge, all of them, hate this idea. It's illegal, they say. The Congressional Hispanic Caucus issued a statement today saying, that's wasteful. Of course, that's not their real concern. Obviously.

According to one "NBC" analyst, it "carries the noxious whiff of military rule."

So, at the very least, these two stories juxtaposed to each other, butted back-to-back are clarifying. In the eyes of the geniuses in charge, our military does not exist for national defense. You thought otherwise? They don't think that.

Our military, they believe, exists only for the defense of other countries. In recent years, we have spent hundreds of millions of dollars helping Jordan, Egypt, Israel, Libya. Other countries protect their borders. That's great, said the panel on the "Morning Joe".

But defending our own borders is a crime against humanity. Your son is welcome to die in Syria, as one American soldier already has. That's patriotic. But defending America? Totally and completely immoral. Who put these people in charge exactly? You know exactly what they think of the country. Not much.

David Tafuri is a former State Department official. He joins us now. Now, David, these two stories really tell you everything. You have people - bipartisan, it's not just Democrats at all - saying we have a moral obligation to keep the borders of Syria intact.

We don't want unauthorized people coming into Syria - the Kurds, the Persians - we've got to keep them out. But to use our military to protect our borders, that's the whiff of military rule. It's immoral. How does that work?

DAVID TAFURI, FORMER STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIAL: Well, that's not why we have US soldiers in Syria. It's not to protect the borders. It's primarily to fight terrorism. In fact, to fight ISIS.

I was just in Iraq three weeks ago again. When I saw there, what I saw is that ISIS is almost defeated. It's lost its territory in Iraq. It's lost its territory in Syria. But remember it was created out of Syria. So, it's a precarious situation.

Moreover, the fundamental reasons why ISIS came into being are not gone yet. There are still divisions in Iraq, divisions in Syria, problems with the government that created ISIS. And, therefore, we need to be there to finish the job with ISIS.

CARLSON: But, actually, did the US government and or our 2,000 troops or the Assad government do more to fight ISIS? Oh, wait. Let me answer that question. I know that Nikki Haley is telling us it's a living hell and Assad is Satan. But, actually, bad guy; did a lot to fight ISIS. I mean, let's be honest about that.

TAFURI: He's done little to fight ISIS.

CARLSON: Oh, OK.

TAFURI: In fact, many think that's he's also party responsible for letting ISIS be there because it's a convenient foe to have.

CARLSON: Who are the who think that?

TAFURI: But let's go back to Trump's policy on Syria because it started quite well. In February, 2017, he does air strikes on Assad because Assad used chemical weapons.

It looked like he was going to actually diverge -

CARLSON: I don't think that's true. That's never been proved.

TAFURI: That's absolutely been proven.

CARLSON: No. It actually has not been proven. We had no one on the ground to verify that as of the moment that we sent airstrikes into Syria in retaliation. We didn't. No American verified that. I don't know that we know that's true.

It's like one of these things that all smart people - oh, it's true. Are you unpatriotic? Are you for Putin? No, I don't believe that's true actually.

TAFURI: Tucker, all of the reporting from the ground -

CARLSON: There was no reporting from the ground.

TAFURI: And including doctors who examined the victims of Assad, said it's true.

CARLSON: Oh, American doctors.

TAFURI: President Trump and the Republican administration believed it was true. That's why they did airstrikes.

CARLSON: I couldn't agree more. And I was skeptical when that happened because my job is not to ratify every decision Trump makes, but to explain what, I think, is right for our country.

So, why is it we sent 2,000 troops into Syria in the middle of a conflict we don't even understand, but it's immoral to send them to keep the invasion on our southern border from continuing into our country, how does that work?

TAFURI: Let's talk about Syria first and then we'll about -

CARLSON: We're almost out of time.

TAFURI: So, the troops are in Syria for very important reasons. Remember, these are special forces troops. So, they're not doing all of the fighting. They're some of our best fighters, but they're also training the indigenous forces in Syria and they made a lot of progress working with the Syrian Kurds.

And the Syrian Kurds are our friends. And the Syrian Kurds have put their lives on the line to fight ISIS with us. And if we pull out suddenly, we're leaving them to be -

CARLSON: How about the South Californians who were born in this, including me. I'm a native South Californian. No one is looking out for my interest because I'm not a Syrian Kurd.

TAFURI: You're right. We have every right to protect our border and President Trump put forward a border proposal with a budget to Congress in order to do that. He failed to push that through. It was a failure in leadership.

CARLSON: So, where is it immoral to protect our country with our military?

TAFURI: It's not immoral. It is moral to protect our country. If we have to, if there's a crisis situation, we should protect our country with our military.

CARLSON: We've got 11 million people living here illegally. That's not a crisis?

TAFURI: The appropriate force to protect the border is the Border Patrol, which comes under the Department of Homeland Security. And President Trump put forward a proposal to fund them and he should be able to push that through Congress.

CARLSON: The left wants to abolish ICE.

TAFURI: He should not treat a situation that's not a crisis as a crisis.

CARLSON: Not a crisis. But Syrian Kurds - I want my son to go fight on behalf of the Syrian Kurds.

TAFURI: ISIS which is responsible for deaths in America and across Europe, that's who we're fighting.

CARLSON: OK. I appreciate it. David, thank you.

TAFURI: Thank you.

CARLSON: On the left, you may have noticed everything is about race. Everything! Even things that have nothing to do with race. Most things are about economics, by the way. It doesn't matter. One channel is calling president a racist for mocking Barack Obama. Part of a long theme. We'll get to it in a minute.

CARLSON: Well, a lot of people hate the president. So, of course, everything he does must be motivated by racial animus because racism is bad. So, of course, Trump would be a bad racist.

Yesterday, on CNN, former White House Communications Director Jen Psaki said that President Trump's Cheatin' Obama nickname was not just weird, it was racist.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEN PSAKI, FORMER WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR: Given Trump's history, you can also guess there might be racial undertones there. He was the founder of the birther movement. Perhaps I'm going to a very evil place with that, but I think history tells us that's a possibility.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: I don't know evil. Just like weird and confusing. OK, maybe it's racist. How? Never explained.

Meanwhile, over at CNN, commentator Tara Setmayer said it's OK to call black Republicans racial slurs. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRISTOPHER HARRIS, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF UNHYPHENATED AMERICA: It takes somebody with very thick skin to go out there and be black and say 'I'm a Republican, I'm a conservative,' because what's going to happen is they're going to come on your network and they're going to be called everything (INAUDIBLE), they're going to called an Uncle Tom (EXPLETIVE DELETED) and everything like that.

TARA SETMAYER, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR: What are you talking about?

And so, first things first -

HARRIS: Are you going to sit there and act like that's not true?

SETMAYER: Well, if you act like it and someone calls you out on it, then we can't do anything about that. Maybe the messengers need to be better.

HARRIS: So it's OK to actually call someone a particular name as long as you feel like they're acting like that? Is that what you're saying?

SETMAYER: I didn't say that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Poor Don Lemon. Nice guy. The show is really unbelievable.

Christopher Harris was on it the other night. He's the man you saw sitting there. He is the executive director of Unhyphenated America and he joins us tonight.

So, I watched that clip. And, first, I thought - I felt so bad for you. But I also thought it was kind of an amazing moment where you basically had someone defending the use of racial slurs because they're political expedient.

HARRIS: Well, what happened, Tucker, the left showed who they really are. Of course, Tara calls herself a conservative and a Republican, but, yes - well, we'll let her say what she wants to say.

But at the end of the day, what the left does, they try to put everybody in a box.

CARLSON: Yes.

HARRIS: And we with Unhyphenated America, what we believe is America is best when it's unhyphenated. That if you believe in, if you embrace, if you understand that - and embrace the principles of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, then you're an American and there's no need for any prefix or suffix. You're just an American.

And so, trying to put everybody into a particular box, saying that you must think a particular way because of your paint job, as one of my buddies says, the melanin content in your skin, is one of the problems that the left has.

And what they're doing is they're focusing on identity politics. And they try to say, well, Donald Trump, obviously, must be a racist because, well, look at the lack of diversity without kind of doing some critical analysis and saying, well, how many black people actually applied for a White House internship.

And even then, when you look at what exactly what happened with Ms. Setmayer is that she just vilified any black person who doesn't toe the lines.

CARLSON: Exactly. So, what happens - I mean, one of the reasons for the hysteria, I think, is Trump actually got a higher percentage of the black vote than the Republican who ran before him - Mitt Romney. Not a ton, but more. So, that freaked them out.

But what happens to the country long term if you encourage everyone in it, of all colors, to think of themselves first as members of a racial or ethnic group. What happens over time?

HARRIS: Well, balkanization. The term a lot of people are not familiar with it. But the Balkan region, what you have is a lot of different tribes, different groups of people who are all constantly warring against each other.

And one of the things - we are the United States of America. I mean, you're maybe a Virginian, or you're a South Carolinian or a Texan, whatever like that, and so you might have a certain amount of pride for being from the state that you're from, but at the end of the day we're all Americans. We have something unifying our culture.

Once again, it's those beliefs in life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness and it's one of those things that they keep trying to push these identity politics to say that you must think a particular way because the color of your skin.

But, more importantly, they want you believe - they want me to believe that because of the color of my skin that I am inherently a victim, that I will always be a victim and that I should vote a particular way for the people who, I guess, they want to protect me.

But we can look at the black community and here's the reality. What hasn't gotten better in the past 50 years, as long as blacks have been voting, 70- plus percent for the Democratic Party.

No one can say that things have gotten better from economic standpoint. The schools haven't gotten better. Economically, we're not doing better. Family-wise, we're not doing better.

But yet, these are the points that they keep wanting to push with these identity politics issues and it's just really maddening.

CARLSON: Do you think - quickly - that maybe the identity politics is designed to distract people from thinking about their actual circumstances, from asking the questions you just raised, which is like, is my life better, am I making more, is my family better off.

If they can wave the red flag of race in front of you, maybe you won't think about those things.

HARRIS: The reality is - I attended McLean Bible Church, which is a huge church. It's an ethnically diverse church. I mean, I always say that the culture is Christian, but is an ethnically diverse church. We have over 100 different cultures - excuse me, ethnicities represented in our church.

And when you have people interacting one-on-one, there's no real issues of racism.

CARLSON: Exactly. And church is the best possible example. Thank you very much. That was great.

HARRIS: Thanks for having me.

CARLSON: Google is expanding research efforts in China that could eventually help the Chinese military overcome the American military. And that's terrifyingly the more you learn about it. The most recent installment of our "Tech Tyranny" series is coming up next.

CARLSON: All this week, we're airing special reports on "Tech Tyranny" looking at how big tech companies are getting more and more power and endangering a lot of things that we think are important, like democracy and clear thinking.

Here's another example. China's military is obsessed with artificial intelligence and is investing massive resources into developing an advantage over our military in artificial intelligence.

Eric Schmidt chairs Alphabet. That's the parent company of Google. He's admitted that China will soon be the world's leader in AI and they'll use it for military purposes.

He's right. Maybe.

Now, Google is dramatically expanding its artificial intelligence research operations in China, which is bolstering an effort that could eventually imperil security of this country.

Paul Scharre is the author of "Army of None: Autonomous Weapons and the Future of War", which looks like a horrifying book. I haven't read it yet, but I plan to. Paul joins us tonight.

Thanks, Paul, for coming on.

PAUL SCHARRE, "ARMY OF NONE: AUTONOMOUS WEAPONS AND THE FUTURE OF WAR" AUTHOR: Thanks for having me.

CARLSON: So, give us the overview of this. Did I characterize it fairly, do you think?

SCHARRE: Look, it's not surprising that Google is looking to make research investments in China. China has got top-tier AI talent. Human capital is key here. And they've got access to a lot of data.

China will have 20 percent of the world's data by 2020. And data is the fuel that powers machine learning.

And so, with a company like Google, they want access to all that data. So, they've said, yes, (INAUDIBLE) setting up more research in China. And that is concerning for the United States.

CARLSON: So, I guess, what I am confused by, so Google describes itself as a multinational company. Really, a kind of corporation of the world.

But it was incubated here. And everything about Google fundamentally is American. It wouldn't have been possible to start Google in China. And yet, Google doesn't seem to feel any obligation whatsoever to the US government or to the American people. So, how does that work exactly?

SCHARRE: Look, this is capitalism.

CARLSON: It's disgusting, actually.

SCHARRE: These companies are responsible to shareholders. They're not accountable to the American people, and so they're going to do what's in their business interests.

And if there is a business interest, they move overseas. They set up research center to offshore jobs. They're going to do that.

CARLSON: So, American taxpayers subsidize the education of the people who founded Google and who work there and we create the regulatory and legal framework possible for it to start.

Again, no other company like this has started in Europe, for example. Certainly not in Asia. So, we make it possible. And then, they turn around and undermine the national security of the country.

I know that people describe as market capitalism, but that seems immoral to me.

SCHARRE: Look, at the end of the day, we are in a technology race. And it's not just China. It's other countries as well.

Vladimir Putin has said whoever controls AI will lead the world.

France! France just released a new plan on artificial intelligence. We're going to have to compete. We're going to have to make US an attractive place for people to come and invest and do AI research and found companies and grow them. And we're going to have to win this race by being faster than others.

CARLSON: Here's another thing that confuses me. And since you've covered it, maybe you've got the answer. So, companies like Google are big on importing talent. You and I understand why. And they argue that we just don't have enough engineers, for example. So, we need to bring them in on H1B visas.

Is there any thought by the billionaires who run these companies, hey, maybe we should take some of our billions and invest in American education. This country isn't producing an adequate number of scientists. Maybe we can help with that. Or because they feel no obligation to the country, only to their shareholders. They don't feel that?

SCHARRE: I think some of these leaders do. You see Eric Schmidt, the former chairman of Alphabet, Google's parent company was part of the Defense Department's Innovation Advisory Board.

He has been very active in talking to people at the Pentagon about how the United States can retain its leadership in artificial intelligence.

So, some of these leaders care.

CARLSON: Really? Because Andrew Carnegie put a library in every town in America once he got rich here. I don't see any of these guys giving back really in any way to the country. They seem just to be taking from it. Only left wing.

SCHARRE: I think a lot of them could do more, right? And more philanthropy from billionaires would be great. Yes.

CARLSON: Yes. It would be great. And we should demand it because this country made their fortunes possible. I think. Paul, thank you for coming on. I appreciate it.

Hillary Clinton says the NRA, Russia, sexism, a ton of other things, all are to blame for her defeat in 2016. A lot of you are going to think why is she still talking like this? Is she OK? A sincere question. Next.

CARLSON: It's been nearly 18 months - we've been keeping track - and Hillary Clinton's blame train is not even close to running out of fuel. It's getting concerning.

Well, speaking on Tuesday night at the Wing, which is a women-only club in New York - because it's women-only, it's not sexist - Clinton began blaming everybody to the NRA to misogyny itself for her defeat in the 2016 election. Here's part of it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, LOST TO DONALD TRUMP IN 2016 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION: Before the Comey letter, I was ahead. I got more votes than anybody in history except one term of President Obama.

Every day that goes by, more evidence, more proof about fake news and the Russians and Cambridge Analytica, misogyny and sexism.

I've taken on the NRA for years. And they've spent more money against me than they've ever spent against anybody. And now, we know the Russians paid for some of it. Paid for actors who are Russian agents, personnel to dress up in those very attractive jail outfits and go around in a mock jail where people could yell, lock her up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: We know who's on MSNBC's website at midnight every night. That's not a political speech. That was more like group therapy.

And honestly, the easy thing would be to make fun of Hillary Clinton. "Ooh, she's so wrong."

But it's past that. This is sad. Will anyone help her? She is crying out for? Where are her friends? Her husband? The DNC? It's like watching someone you know fall apart. It's poignant and tragic. And someone ought to help.

Tammy Bruce is a radio host and she joins us tonight. Tammy, I'm only half joking. Whatever else this is, this is not empowering for women. As the father of three daughters, I can say that conclusively.

TAMMY BRUCE, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE PRESIDENT: Right. And, look, I mean, there is a point where you never think you'd say this, but you do begin to feel sorry for her.

And as a political person, look, a part of what her complaint was at that event was that Fox News is trying to "impeach her." In other words that there's coverage of her on this network.

There's actually - interestingly, of course, the complaints have come from other Democrats across the networks, people who actually work for her campaign.

But she is in a unique opportunity here - in a unique position where since she is getting coverage and she clearly is searching for relevance, she could talk about policy.

CARLSON: Yes.

BRUCE: She could use this so that we would actually be discussing an argument that she could be having about -

CARLSON: Well, that's such a smart point.

BRUCE: And also, frankly, maybe then she would be on the Tucker Carlson show and you could have this conversation.

CARLSON: Because actually she knows a lot. She's not stupid. And she's been around a long time and she - her claim to fame always was I've read the policies, only I've - and there's some truth in that actually and she could be doing that, but she's not.

BRUCE: She's been in the White House. She's obviously been in the Senate. She's been the Secretary of State. And yet, this has devolved into this group therapy dynamic where she's going over the same complaints that people there in that group, maybe they've read her book, they know what her complaints are, but she's also then inserting news of the day, like now suddenly it's the Cambridge Analytica and it's the NRA because that's the news that's happening now.

At this point, it's almost as though she's on an episode of intervention where people really should try to get her into the van to get her to the plane, to get her to the place where she can find some peace because it does get to a point where that's a real - it's almost an abdication of a responsibility she could have to all of her fans and supporters to really deal seriously with the issues because they too want solutions.

And she's still, with this great attention internationally, is not using the platform she has to present those solutions. And it's sad and I think that there could be - even though I would disagree with her solutions, we at least then could move forward on these issues and try to make a difference.

CARLSON: Well, that's exactly right. We could add to the sum total of the conversation, which I think is important, even if you disagree. And we try to do it every night.

By the way, that's her speaking live. We actually don't have a huge desire to cover everything Hillary Clinton despite her claim, but I think it's interesting - and can I speak one other point?

BRUCE: Yes.

CARLSON: The irony which people are not kind of perceiving is that her party has moved very far from where she was. We all long for a time when Hillary Clinton was the most radical person in the Democratic Party. And she's way too moderate for Democrats by and large right now.

BRUCE: And that actually is an interesting position she could be in. In arguing the things that she and her husband used to represent, which was balanced budgets and getting people off of welfare and into work and all of that, I mean, if she wanted to be serious, that's what she could be doing.

Arguments about how to improve the quality of women's lives. You could argue that - she says nobody else has been attacked like her and nobody else was told to go away like she's been told to go away.

But Al Gore and John McCain and John Kerry actually continue to talk about policy. We can disagree with what they stood for, but as a woman, I think that there are so many other opportunities with the platform she has. And her own party is saying, enough is enough at this point.

CARLSON: Yes. If one of my kids acted like that, I'd be very upset.

Really quickly, so Christian privilege, this is a new category. A seminar at George Washington University here in Washington will examine how Christians get "unmerited perks" and have built-in advantages over everybody else in America.

If you actually look at the numbers, Christians are not - anyway, are actually not thriving in this country. This is all measured. But what do you make of this? To say this out loud, it seems like a change.

BRUCE: Well, I don't identify as a Christian. I believe in God. I believe that Jesus is the guy. I think it's a very serious thing to identify as a Christian. And so, I'm taking it seriously and slowly.

But as looking from the outside, what I see as a political commentator and analyst is Christians maybe have a privilege of being persecuted and attacked and martyred around the world. I mean, it is a remarkable attack dynamic. Even here at home.

CARLSON: I know.

BRUCE: Facebook tried to apologize for refusing a Catholic university's ad that features Jesus on the cross because it was too violent.

Remember the Chick-fil-A controversy, the so-called controversy, because of its owner being a Christian man.

Even the attacks that Billy Graham at his death went under because of his Christian faith. So, there's no privilege except I think to be mocked.

CARLSON: There isn't. Tammy Bruce, great to see you.

BRUCE: Thank you.

CARLSON: Up next, reflecting our commitment to hard news, zombie racoons. Stay tuned.

CARLSON: Youngstown, Ohio was living in a state of fear tonight. That city has survived de-industrialization, crime, opioids. Now it faces an even more profound threat, zombie raccoons.

In the past week, Youngstown police have responded to more than a dozen calls of bizarre behavior during the day by these ordinarily nocturnal critters.

No one has captured this on camera yet. So, imagine the raccoon in this file video as a zombie.

According to one eyewitness, a raccoon has walked up to him as he walked his dog, reared up on its hind legs and then poised to attack, abruptly fell back as though having a seizure.

According to authorities, this isn't a virus. It's something called distemper. It makes raccoons lose their fear of human beings.

Our stage director, Louis, just said this happened to him in Toledo. So, it's possible it's an Ohio thing. Either way, stay safe tonight.

That's about it for us tonight. Tune in every night at 8 p.m. to the show that's the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and especially groupthink. We will see you tomorrow.

But, first, live from New York City, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Sean Hannity.

urn:contentItem:60JX-0DT1-F03R-N2GN-00000-00The legal test and the remedy are not two separate steps; they are two sides of the same coin2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:33:52ZLexisNexisThe legal test and the remedy are not two separate steps; they are two sides of the same coinPablo Ibanez Colomo

Aug 11, 2020( Chillin' Competition: http://chillingcompetition.com Delivered by Newstex) Following two of my latest posts - a though experiment[1] on smartphones and cameras, and an update[2] on Slovak Telekom[3][1][4]- some of you have contacted me about the central argument I develop in them.My main point in both is that the remedy is not an afterthought that is irrelevant when establishing an infringement. The remedy - or, more precisely, what a finding of liability would entail - is central to determine whether there is a breach in the first place.This statement is true as a matter of positive law - Van den Bergh Foods[5] encapsulates the essence of the case law - and is also true from a normative standpoint - as the post on smartphones and cameras sought to explain.The messages I have received following these posts are certainly sensible. How can the remedy determine the applicable legal test? Is it not getting the case backwards?

Should we not establish an infringement first and then figure out the way to remedy it?These questions, no doubt reasonable, are based on a fundamental assumption, which is that the finding of an infringement and a remedy are two separate steps, independent of one another.I do not believe this assumption reflects the reality of the interaction between legal tests and remedies. More importantly, I do not believe the Court treats the infringement and the remedy as separate steps. They are rather two sides of the same coin.The remedy reliably tells us what a case is about, and what the legal test isA finding of infringement and a remedy are so closely intertwined that the single most reliable way to tell whether there is a competition law breach is to inquire about how to bring the alleged breach to an end. In other words: to understand what a firm has done (and whether what it has done is prohibited), the best approach is to ask the claimant what the alleged infringer would need to do to comply with the law.This point can be illustrated by reference to refusal to deal scenarios. These cases are not always easy to spot, and the lines are sometimes blurred between them and other legal categories, including tying and 'margin squeeze'.How to tell apart one category from the other? Inquire what the endgame would be. If the endgame is one in which a court or authority mandates (directly or indirectly, implicitly or explicitly) shared access to an input or an infrastructure, then the case raises the issues that are typical of refusal to deal cases. For the same reason, indispensability would be an element of the legal test.Suppose, conversely, the remedy is a different one. For instance, an obligation not to require exclusivity from the firm's customers. If so, we would be in Hoffmann-La Roche and Intel territory (where nobody has ever thought of making indispensability an element of the legal test).These statements are hardly revolutionary. It is, in essence, what the Court held in Van den Bergh Foods and then in TeliaSonera. In Van den Bergh Foods, the firm argued that indispensability was an element of the legal test. Both the General Court and the Court of Justice, in light of the endgame, concluded that the case belonged in the Hoffmann-La Roche/Intel family, and rejected the argument.The remedy is routinely considered when calibrating the legal testThe history of competition law also teaches us that the remedy (that is, what the case would involve in practice) has been routinely considered when designing the appropriate legal test.In particular, courts tend to craft strict legal tests where a finding of infringement would demand the administration of regulatory-like remedy (such as mandating access obligations and setting the terms and conditions under which access is to be granted).Again, this idea is hardly revolutionary, and is part of our law. Why is indispensability part of the legal test in refusal to deal cases? Magill and Bronner seem to reflect deep awareness of the implications of a finding of infringement. Think of Magill. Again, the question is: what is the endgame of ruling that a refusal to license copyright-protected information is abusive? Imposing a duty to license on the right holder. By definition, there is a tension between such an endgame and the logic of intellectual property systems (the very point of which the right to refuse to license).It is not a surprise, against this background, that the Court confined to 'exceptional circumstances' the instances in which Article 102 TFEU can be relied upon to impose a duty to license (thereby minimising the tension with intellectual property systems).The uncertainties and complexities of administering a remedy have als been mentioned as factors to consider when crafting a legal test. In his celebrated article[6] on essential facilities, Phillip Areeda - the ultimate centrist in our field - expressed the view that '[n]o court should impose a duty to deal that it cannot explain or adequately and reasonably supervise' and went on to warn against the imposition of regulatory-like obligations.The EU experience shows that competition authorities do not fare much better than courts when it comes to the administration of these proactive remedies. The failure of the media player remedy in Microsoft I often comes up in these discussions. The principles-based approach to the question in Google Shopping and Android, and the resulting state of limbo (which appears to continue), another one.Big Tech and legal tests: the question that will not go awayThe discussion above gives, hopefully, a sense of what is going on, from a legal standpoint, in relation to Big Tech. Many of these cases demand regulatory-like intervention, and this, more frequently and more intensely than in the past. It would seem that some competition authorities are more confident than they used to about their ability to redesign products and to tweak business models (other authorities, like the CMA, are more cautious, as the Final Report[7] on digital advertising shows).This increased confidence tends to trickle down into the interpretation of competition law provisions. The link between the nature of the remedy and the legal test, which acted as a limit on intervention, is now questioned (with the institutional implications that follow, in particular in a decentralised system). Fascinating, and potentially transformative, times.[1][8] Speaking of which, the AG Saugmandsgaard e's Opinion is out on 9 September. [ 1]: https://chillingcompetition.com/2020/07/21/is-it-an-abuse-for-apple-to-embed-a-camera-in-its-iphones-what-is-special-and-different-about-digital-cases/ [ 2]: https://chillingcompetition.com/2020/07/24/on-case-c-165-19-p-slovak-telekom-an-upcoming-development-under-the-radar/ [ 3]: http://curia.europa.eu/juris/fiche.jsf?id=C%3B165%3B19%3BPV%3B1%3BP%3B1%3BC2019%2F0165%2FP&oqp=&for=&mat=or&lgrec=en&jge=&td=%3BALL&jur=C%2CT%2CF&dates=&pcs=Oor&lg=&parties=Slovak%2BTelekom&pro=&nat=or&cit=none%252CC%252CCJ%252CR%252C2008E%252C%252C%252C%252C%252C%252C%252C%252C%252C%252Ctrue%252Cfalse%252Cfalse&language=en&avg=&cid=13752410 [ 4]: #_ftn1 [ 5]: http://curia.europa.eu/juris/showPdf.jsf?text=&docid=65800&pageIndex=0&doclang=en&mode=lst&dir=&occ=first&part=1&cid=13752395 [ 6]: https://www.jstor.org/stable/40843140?seq=1 [ 7]: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/5efc57ed3a6f4023d242ed56/Final_report_1_July_2020_.pdf [ 8]: #_ftnref1

Following two of my latest posts – a though experiment on smartphones and cameras, and an update on Slovak Telekom [1] – some of you have contacted me about the central argument I develop in them. My main point in both is that the remedy is not an aftertho...

Following two of my latest posts – a though experiment on smartphones and cameras, and an update on Slovak Telekom [1] – some of you have contacted me about the central argument I develop in them. My main point in both is that the remedy is not an afterthought that is irrelevant when establishing an infringement. The remedy – or, more precisely, what a finding of liability would entail – is central to determine whether there is a breach in the first place. This statement is true as a matter of positive law – Van den Bergh Foods encapsulates the essence of the case law – and is also true from a normative standpoint – as the post on smartphones and cameras sought to explain. The messages I have received following these posts are certainly sensible. How can the remedy determine the applicable legal test? Is it not getting the case backwards? Should we not establish an infringement first and then figure out the way to remedy it? These questions, no doubt reasonable, are based on a fundamental assumption, which is that the finding of an infringement and a remedy are two separate steps, independent of one another. I do not believe this assumption reflects the reality of the interaction between legal tests and remedies. More importantly, I do not believe the Court treats the infringement and the remedy as separate steps. They are rather two sides of the same coin. The remedy reliably tells us what a case is about, and what the legal test is A finding of infringement and a remedy are so closely intertwined that the single most reliable way to tell whether there is a competition law breach is to inquire about how to bring the alleged breach to an end. In other words: to understand what a firm has done (and whether what it has done is prohibited), the best approach is to ask the claimant what the alleged infringer would need to do to comply with the law. This point can be illustrated by reference to refusal to deal scenarios. These cases are not always easy to spot, and the lines are sometimes blurred between them and other legal categories, including tying and ‘margin squeeze’. How to tell apart one category from the other? Inquire what the endgame would be. If the endgame is one in which a court or authority mandates (directly or indirectly, implicitly or explicitly) shared access to an input or an infrastructure, then the case raises the issues that are typical of refusal to deal cases. For the same reason, indispensability would be an element of the legal test. Suppose, conversely, the remedy is a different one. For instance, an obligation not to require exclusivity from the firm’s customers. If so, we would be in Hoffmann-La Roche and Intel territory (where nobody has ever thought of making indispensability an element of the legal test). These statements are hardly revolutionary. It is, in essence, what the Court held in Van den Bergh Foods and then in TeliaSonera . In Van den Bergh Foods , the firm argued that indispensability was an element of the legal test. Both the General Court and the Court of Justice, in light of the endgame, concluded that the case belonged in the Hoffmann-La Roche / Intel family, and rejected the argument. The remedy is routinely considered when calibrating the legal test The history of competition law also teaches us that the remedy (that is, what the case would involve in practice) has been routinely considered when designing the appropriate legal test. In particular, courts tend to craft strict legal tests where a finding of infringement would demand the administration of regulatory-like remedy (such as mandating access obligations and setting the terms and conditions under which access is to be granted). Again, this idea is hardly revolutionary, and is part of our law. Why is indispensability part of the legal test in refusal to deal cases? Magill and Bronner seem to reflect deep awareness of the implications of a finding of infringement. Think of Magill . Again, the question is: what is the endgame of ruling that a refusal to license copyright-protected information is abusive? Imposing a duty to license on the right holder. By definition, there is a tension between such an endgame and the logic of intellectual property systems (the very point of which the right to refuse to license). It is not a surprise, against this background, that the Court confined to ‘exceptional circumstances’ the instances in which Article 102 TFEU can be relied upon to impose a duty to license (thereby minimising the tension with intellectual property systems). The uncertainties and complexities of administering a remedy have als been mentioned as factors to consider when crafting a legal test. In his celebrated article on essential facilities, Phillip Areeda – the ultimate centrist in our field – expressed the view that ‘[n]o court should impose a duty to deal that it cannot explain or adequately and reasonably supervise’ and went on to warn against the imposition of regulatory-like obligations. The EU experience shows that competition authorities do not fare much better than courts when it comes to the administration of these proactive remedies. The failure of the media player remedy in Microsoft I often comes up in these discussions. The principles-based approach to the question in Google Shopping and Android , and the resulting state of limbo (which appears to continue), another one. Big Tech and legal tests: the question that will not go away The discussion above gives, hopefully, a sense of what is going on, from a legal standpoint, in relation to Big Tech. Many of these cases demand regulatory-like intervention, and this, more frequently and more intensely than in the past. It would seem that some competition authorities are more confident than they used to about their ability to redesign products and to tweak business models (other authorities, like the CMA, are more cautious, as the Final Report on digital advertising shows). This increased confidence tends to trickle down into the interpretation of competition law provisions. The link between the nature of the remedy and the legal test, which acted as a limit on intervention, is now questioned (with the institutional implications that follow, in particular in a decentralised system). Fascinating, and potentially transformative, times. [1] Speaking of which, the AG Saugmandsgaard Øe’s Opinion is out on 9 September.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S34-8331-JBVM-Y27J-00000-00The legal vultures are circling for Facebook;After finally taking responsibility for both content and privacy failures, Zuckerberg will no longer be above the law2018-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:33:52ZLexisNexisEDITORIAL; OPINION COLUMNSPg. 29The legal vultures are circling for FacebookAfter finally taking responsibility for both content and privacy failures, Zuckerberg will no longer be above the lawIain Martin

Spending a couple of years immersed in the messy aftermath of the financial crisis while researching a book on the downfall of RBS and its leader, Fred Goodwin, taught me quite a bit. That the economic cycle of boom and bust can never be ended. That you should sell shares in any company when a chief executive builds a bespoke new headquarters and demands that either a flag or a fountain is put outside the entrance. Out-of-control Goodwin had a fountain and flags, and a Tornado flypast in front of the Queen for the opening of RBS's Edinburgh HQ in 2005. Look what happened next.

However, the single most useful insight that has stuck with me came from the successful chairman (they do exist) of a bank. Stupid questions, he pointed out, are usually the best questions in meetings. It takes confidence and sometimes even humility to ask them.

That came to mind watching tech-savvy media types mock the US senators who cross-examined the Facebookfounder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg in Washington this week. Who were these crumbly old dudes? One, Senator Orrin Hatch, 84, even asked Zuckerberg how, if his company's products were free, Facebookmade any money? What an idiot, Zuck's online fanbase crowed, while the bemused boss smirked and pointed out: "Senator, we sell ads."

This time it was the tech-savvy who had missed the point. The senators are hardly perfect, but they are politicians who must navigate the currents of voter opinion and they understand what good barristers understand. Begin simply by asking the accused where he or she was on the night of the crime. Build up a picture, and steadily get the big themes on the record.

To many consumers who probably have not thought about it, Zuckerberg's "we sell ads" is a rather revealing and clear explanation of a supposedly miraculous business that was promoted by the tech community as the product of innate chino-clad genius. Facebooknever was a touchy-feely, do-good enterprise focused solely on "community", though. The collection of data, and using it to sell adverts and services over which it is now in trouble, is not an aberration. It is Zuckerberg's entire business model.

Another simple question - "Would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?" - got Zuckerberg to wrestle uncomfortably in public with notions of privacy. Facebookknows where its billions of users stayed last night: why is that OK while the Facebookboss's movements are deemed private? One question produced the key admission, a dramatic and critical moment in the evolving history of the internet, in my view. Facebook, said Zuckerberg, was responsible for the content on its platforms. Here he was, finally confessing to being a publisher, culpable like a conventional news service or book publisher for what he allows out there.

The idea, little more than two decades old, that the internet exists in a different and magical category, and that the people making billions out of selling ads against the content they allow to be published have no legal responsibility, was always daft. Yet it persisted, without governments, regulators or (until too late) the media asking what effect this would have on the public sphere.

We now know the outcome, with Russia having used Facebook's services to interfere in elections. The digital takeover also came close to wrecking the model by which the West's free and independent press funded itself, when the tech giants sucked up the overwhelming share of advertising by promising advertisers better access to consumers because big tech was and is spying on its own users.

It is in that context that Zuckerberg's grilling in Washington should be seen. We are only at the start of a long and overdue attempt to address a public policy disaster that will require years of work by legislators in the US, the EU and Britain to reform, and may lead to the break-up of the biggest technology firms to ensure competition.

An accompanying deluge of legal cases should be expected, as parents of children killed by young men radicalised after watching YouTube videos test the law, and victims of data theft or online bullying sue the publishers, the tech giants. It is a lawyer's dream. And then new laws will probably be required.

Throughout the complicated process of reform our politicians need to keep in mind the ethical and economic questions of the internet age. Do we work for the tech giants, or do they work for us? What is in the public interest? Who is in charge? What is for sale? And where is the money? There is another urgent imperative. Although the Facebookscandal deals with the mistakes of the past, for our own safety we should also be thinking about the ethics of the future. The rise of artificial intelligence and robotics will bring innovation, of course, but the Facebookscandal provides a textbook study in the dangers of over-enthusiastic groupthink. Better next time to ask questions early on about the law and ultimate responsibility before the self-programming and self-driving machines are programmed.

The consequences of omission can be serious. A failure to ask early on about the implications of others' actions is a fascinatingly common feature in man-made calamities. It was there in the inadequate provision of lifeboats on the Titanic; there too in the boom that preceded the 1929 crash, and in our own more recent financial crisis, and in what we can see now is the destruction of privacy resulting from the unimpeded rise of Facebookand Google.

Let's not add the unregulated artificial intelligence scandal of 2028 to the list. We have been warned.

The biggest tech firms may be broken up to ensure competition

An accompanying deluge of legal cases should be expected, as parents of children killed by young men radicalised after watching YouTube videos test the law, and victims of data theft or online bullying sue the publishers, the tech giants. It is a lawyer's dream. And then new laws will probably be required.

Throughout the complicated process of reform our politicians need to keep in mind the ethical and economic questions of the internet age. Do we work for the tech giants, or do they work for us? What is in the public interest? Who is in charge? What is for sale? And where is the money? There is another urgent imperative. Although the Facebookscandal deals with the mistakes of the past, for our own safety we should also be thinking about the ethics of the future. The rise of artificial intelligence and robotics will bring innovation, of course, but the Facebookscandal provides a textbook study in the dangers of over-enthusiastic groupthink. Better next time to ask questions early on about the law and ultimate responsibility before the self-programming and self-driving machines are programmed.

The consequences of omission can be serious. A failure to ask early on about the implications of others' actions is a fascinatingly common feature in man-made calamities. It was there in the inadequate provision of lifeboats on the Titanic; there too in the boom that preceded the 1929 crash, and in our own more recent financial crisis, and in what we can see now is the destruction of privacy resulting from the unimpeded rise of Facebookand Google.

Let's not add the unregulated artificial intelligence scandal of 2028 to the list. We have been warned.

The biggest tech firms may be broken up to ensure competition

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S34-8331-JBVM-Y1K1-00000-00The legal vultures are circling for Facebook;After finally taking responsibility for privacy failures, Zuckerberg is no longer above the law2018-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:33:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14The legal vultures are circling for FacebookAfter finally taking responsibility for privacy failures, Zuckerberg is no longer above the lawIain Martin

Spending a couple of years immersed in the messy aftermath of the financial crisis, while researching a book on the downfall of RBS and its leader, Fred Goodwin, taught me quite a bit. That the economic cycle of boom and bust can never be ended. That you should sell shares in any company when a chief executive builds a bespoke new headquarters and demands that either a flag or a fountain is put outside the entrance. Out-of-control Goodwin had a fountain and flags, and a Tornado flypast in front of the Queen for the opening of RBS's Edinburgh HQ in 2005. Look what happened next.

However, the single most useful insight that has stuck with me came from the successful chairman (they do exist) of a bank. Stupid questions, he pointed out, are usually the best questions in meetings. It takes confidence and sometimes even humility to ask them.

That came to mind watching tech-savvy media types mock the US senators who cross-examined the Facebookfounder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg in Washington this week. Who were these crumbly old dudes? One, Senator Orrin Hatch, 84, even asked Zuckerberg how, if his company's products were free, Facebookmade any money? What an idiot, Zuck's online fanbase crowed, while the bemused boss smirked and pointed out: "Senator, we sell ads."

This time it was the tech-savvy who had missed the point. The senators are not perfect, but they are politicians who must navigate the currents of voter opinion and they understand what good barristers understand. Begin simply by asking the accused where he or she was on the night of the crime. Build up a picture, and get the big themes on the record.

To many consumers who probably have not thought about it, Zuckerberg's "we sell ads" is a rather revealing and clear explanation of a supposedly miraculous business that was promoted by the tech community as the product of innate chino-clad genius. Facebooknever was a touchyfeely, do-good enterprise focused solely on "community", though. The collection of data, and using it to sell adverts and services over which it is now in trouble, is not an aberration. It is Zuckerberg's entire business model.

Another simple question - "Would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?" - got Zuckerberg to wrestle uncomfortably in public with notions of privacy. Facebookknows where its billions of users stayed last night: why is that OK while the Facebookboss's movements are deemed private? One question produced the key admission, a dramatic and critical moment in the evolving history of the internet, in my view. Facebook, said Zuckerberg, was responsible for the content on its platforms. Here he was, finally confessing to being a publisher, culpable like a conventional news service or book publisher for what he allows out there.

The idea, little more than two decades old, that the internet exists in a different and magical category, and that the people making billions out of selling ads against the content they allow to be published have no legal responsibility, was always daft. Yet it persisted, without governments, regulators or (until too late) the media asking what effect this would have on the public sphere.

We now know the outcome, with Russia having used Facebook's services to interfere in elections. The digital takeover also came close to wrecking the model by which the West's free and independent press funded itself, when the tech giants sucked up the overwhelming share of advertising by promising advertisers better access to consumers because big tech was and is spying on its own users.

It is in that context that Zuckerberg's grilling in Washington should be seen. We are only at the start of a long and overdue attempt to address a public policy disaster that will require years of work by legislators in the US, the EU and Britain to reform, and may lead to the break-up of the biggest technology firms to ensure competition.

An accompanying deluge of legal cases should be expected, as parents of children killed by young men radicalised after watching YouTube videos test the law, and victims of data theft or online bullying sue the publishers, the tech giants. It is a lawyer's dream.

Throughout the process of reform our politicians need to keep in mind the ethical and economic questions of the internet age. Do we work for the tech giants, or do they work for us? What is in the public interest? Who is in charge? What is for sale? There is another urgent imperative.

Although the Facebookscandal deals with the mistakes of the past, for our own safety we should also be thinking about the ethics of the future. The rise of artificial intelligence and robotics will bring innovation, of course, but the Facebookscandal provides a textbook study in the dangers of over-enthusiastic groupthink. Better next time to ask questions early on about the law and ultimate responsibility before the self-programming and self-driving machines are programmed.

The consequences of omission can be serious. A failure to ask early on about the implications of others' actions is a fascinatingly common feature in man-made calamities. It was there in the inadequate provision of lifeboats on the Titanic; there too in the boom that preceded the 1929 crash, and in our own more recent financial crisis, and in what we can see now is the destruction of privacy resulting from the unimpeded rise of Facebookand Google.

Let's not add the unregulated artificial intelligence scandal of 2028 to the list. We have been warned.

The biggest tech firms may be broken up to ensure competition
